<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 722, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 210, 905, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 178, 293]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|> 9702/31 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 359, 317]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|> May/June 2024 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 401]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 222, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 285, 450]]<|/det|> Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 808, 466]]<|/det|> Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|> Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|> Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 480, 512]]<|/det|> Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 358, 527]]<|/det|> Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 798, 544]]<|/det|> You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 544, 892, 575]]<|/det|> You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 320, 590]]<|/det|> You may use a calculator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 590, 578, 606]]<|/det|> You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 212, 649]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 651, 384, 666]]<|/det|> The total mark for this paper is 40. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 667, 729, 682]]<|/det|> The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[712, 712, 907, 841]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[386, 868, 611, 884]]<|/det|> This document has 12 pages.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 737, 89]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 96, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 594, 120]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate an electrical circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 918, 182]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with a metre rule with a wire attached. You have also been provided with six identical resistors. Four of the resistors are connected in series and attached to a wooden block. The other resistors are labelled X and Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 196, 144, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 196, 485, 214]]<|/det|>
● Set up the circuit shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 223, 895, 505]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 521, 591, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 553, 180, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>E</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 553, 468, 571]]<|/det|>
F, G and H are crocodile clips.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 584, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
\(n\) resistors on the wooden block are connected in parallel with X. Connect F so that \(n = 2\), as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 631, 175, 650]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 631, 918, 650]]<|/det|>
The distance between G and H is \(y.\) Attach H to the wire so that \(y\) is approximately \(50 \text{cm.}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 662, 176, 680]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 662, 339, 680]]<|/det|>
Close the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 694, 176, 712]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 694, 522, 712]]<|/det|>
Record \(n\), \(y\) and the ammeter reading \(I\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 725, 917, 742]]<|/det|>
<form>n = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 756, 917, 774]]<|/det|>
<form>y = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 787, 917, 804]]<|/det|>
<form>I = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 817, 171, 836]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 817, 336, 836]]<|/det|>
Open the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 834, 920, 853]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 460, 89]]<|/det|>
Connect Z as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 100, 722, 240]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 259, 534, 277]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 290, 920, 324]]<|/det|>
When Z is connected in parallel with the first of the resistors on the block, the total value of \(n\) is reduced by 0.5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 336, 630, 354]]<|/det|>
For the arrangement in Fig. 1.2, the value of \(n\) is 1.5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 368, 180, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 368, 339, 384]]<|/det|>
Close the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 399, 175, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 397, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
Change the position of H on the wire until the value of \(I\) is as close as possible to your value in (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 446, 176, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 445, 329, 463]]<|/det|>
Record \(n\) and \(y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 490, 917, 508]]<|/det|>
<form>n = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 522, 917, 541]]<|/det|>
<form>y = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 553, 176, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 553, 336, 570]]<|/det|>
Open the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 584, 176, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 584, 311, 602]]<|/det|>
Disconnect Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 600, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 761, 91]]<|/det|>
Vary \(n\) by changing the position of F and connecting and disconnecting Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
For each value of \(n\), change the position of H until the value of \(I\) is as close as possible to your value in (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 881, 168]]<|/det|>
Repeat until you have six sets of values of \(n\) and \(y\). Include your values from (a) and (b).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 178, 907, 200]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\frac{n}{n + 1}\) to two significant figures in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 521, 920, 540]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 553, 144, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 553, 175, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 552, 672, 574]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(y\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\frac{n}{n + 1}\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 552, 920, 571]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 584, 180, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 584, 457, 602]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 584, 920, 602]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 615, 180, 633]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 615, 608, 633]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 803, 917, 821]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 834, 917, 853]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 851, 920, 868]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 724, 91]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the quantities \(y\) and \(n\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 98, 562, 125]]<|/det|>
\[y = -\frac{Pn}{n + 1} +Q\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 405, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 680, 183]]<|/det|>
Using your answers in **(d)(iii)**, determine the values of \(P\) and \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 346, 198]]<|/det|>
Give appropriate units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 255, 917, 274]]<|/det|>
<form>P = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 288, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
<form>Q = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 305, 920, 323]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 335, 143, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 334, 354]]<|/det|>
Theory suggests that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[468, 358, 531, 389]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{P}{Q} = \frac{X}{C}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 870, 415]]<|/det|>
where the resistance \(X\) of resistor X is \(12 \Omega\) and C is the resistance of the whole circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 427, 564, 446]]<|/det|>
Use your values in **(e)** to determine a value for C.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 600, 920, 619]]<|/det|>
<form>C = .................................................... $\Omega$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 632, 920, 651]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 20]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 72, 210, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Wrap one end of the copper wire tightly three times around the centre of the rod, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 112, 737, 234]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 247, 534, 266]]<|/det|>
<mark>[b]> 2.2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 278, 212, 295]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 278, 650, 297]]<|/det|>
Slide a \(50\mathrm{g}\) slotted mass onto each end of the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 310, 212, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[233, 310, 586, 327]]<|/det|>
Record the mass \(m\) on one end of the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 339, 920, 358]]<|/det|>
<form>m = ....................................................... g

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 371, 212, 389]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 371, 920, 420]]<|/det|>
Adjust the positions of the masses so that they are equally spaced from the centre of the rod and their centres are approximately \(3\mathrm{cm}\) apart, as shown in Fig. 2.3. You may need to use some of the adhesive putty to keep the masses in position.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 574, 534, 593]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 72, 584, 88]]<|/det|>

This is produced for each series of examinations and is freely available to download at www.cambridgeinternational.org after the live examination series.
